init

public void init()
Description copied from class: java.applet.Applet
Called by the browser or applet viewer to inform this applet that it has been loaded into the system. It is always called before the first time that the start method is called.

A subclass of Applet should override this method if it has initialization to perform. For example, an applet with threads would use the init method to create the threads and the destroy method to kill them.

The implementation of this method provided by the Applet class does nothing.

See Also:
Applet.destroy(), Applet.start(), Applet.stop()

print

public void print(java.lang.String msg)
Prints a message in the text window using the normal text style.

Parameters:
msg - The text message to display.

printCode

public void printCode(java.lang.String code)
Prints a message using a "code" style of text (smaller, sansserif). The message is terminated with a newline marker.

Parameters:
code - The line of code or text message to display.

printError

public void printError(java.lang.String error)
Prints an error message in the text window using the error style. The message will be prefixed with a newline and "ERROR:", and terminated with a newline.

Parameters:
error - The contents of the error message.

printLine

public void printLine(java.lang.String msg)
Prints a message with a terminal newline marker in the text window using the normal text style.

Parameters:
msg - The text message to display.

run

public void run()
Description copied from interface: java.lang.Runnable
When an object implementing interface Runnable is used to create a thread, starting the thread causes the object's run method to be called in that separately executing thread.

The general contract of the method run is that it may take any action whatsoever.

Specified by:
run in interface java.lang.Runnable
See Also:
Thread.run()
